question: CAPTAIN, IF YOUR MOTHER SAW YOU DO THAT, SHE'D BE VERY UPSET!
answer: Crosses the gap. His men follow. Okay, Wade, your turn.

question: What the hell were you doing? Drawing fire!
answer: Worked, didn't it?

question: You tryin' to get yourself killed?
answer: Don't need to, the Krauts go that covered. Trailed by a RADIOMAN, dashes through the fire and dives into a sludge- filled crater. He surfaces, sees Sarge and Reiben, and reels from a horrific smell. Their conversation is repeatedly broken by FIRING And Jesus Christ! What the hell are we swimming in?

question: Who cares?
answer: I care. Don't you know what Caen's famous for, Sarge?

question: Frogs?
answer: Lingerie.

question: Yeah? So?
answer: So, you ever heard of employee discounts? My uncle sells shoes, gets twenty-five percent off everything in the line, got a closet filled with the best looking shoes you ever seen. Just picture some French number been spending all day, every day, making cream-colored, shear-body negligees with gentle-lift silk cups and gathered empire waists, what the hell you think she wears at night?

question: So, you ever heard of employee discounts? My uncle sells shoes, gets twenty-five percent off everything in the line, got a closet filled with the best looking shoes you ever seen. Just picture some French number been spending all day, every day, making cream-colored, shear-body negligees with gentle-lift silk cups and gathered empire waists, what the hell you think she wears at night?
answer: Reiben, how the hell do you know so much about lingerie?

question: Lingerie is my life, sir. My mother's got a shop in Brooklyn, I grew up in it, from the time I could crawl, we carry Caen lingerie, it's the best there is, it's all I been thinking about since the invasion.
answer: There's a war on, good chance they're not still making lingerie in Caen.

question: Oh, Captain, they'll always make lingerie, it's one of the three basic needs of man -- food, shelter, silk teddies. Miller Dream on, private. Happy to, sir.
answer: Maybe the war's over.

question: I don't think so, Captain.
answer: Stay at it until you get fire control. Keep 'em down, wait for the navy.

question: Runs over the broken ground and makes it to the sandbagged H.Q. He stumbles down the make-shift stairs. Miller, Company B, Second Rangers.
answer: ...I understand your problem, but if we don't get those tanks off-loaded by 0600, we're going to have an entire division up at Caen with its ass hanging out of its pants...

question: My what? Find a chaplain.
answer: ...alright, let me know when. Have the Second and Third Regiments hold at St. Michel until we get those tanks. Aide Yes, sir. Report.

question: Sector four is secured, we put out the last three German one-fifty-fives, found them about two miles in from Ponte du Hoc.
answer: Resistance?

question: A company, Wehrmacht, no artillery, we took twenty-three prisoners, turned them over to intelligence.
answer: Casualties?

question: Fourty-four, twenty one dead. They didn't want to give up those one-fifty-fives, sir.
answer: It was a hard assignment, that's why you got it.

question: Yes, sir.
answer: Where are your men now?

question: Pinned down, a mile east of here, waiting for some help from the navy guns.
answer: I'm sending Simpson to take over for you, the division is going to Caen, you're not coming with us, I have something else for you.

question: Sir?
answer: There's a Private James Ryan who parachuted in with the Hundred-and- First near Ramelle. I want you to take a squad up there. If he's alive, bring him back to the beach for debarkation. Take whoever you need, you've got your pick of the company.

question: A private, sir?
answer: He's the last of four brothers, the other three were killed in action. This is straight from the Chief of Staff.

question: But, sir...I...I...
answer: Spit it out, Captain.

question: Respectfully, sir, sending men all the way up to Ramelle to save one private doesn't make a fucking, goddamned bit of sense. Sir.
answer: You think just because you hold the Congressional Medal of Honor, you can say any damn thing you please to your superior officers?

question: Yes, sir, more or less.
answer: Alright, I'll give you that. Continue.

question: The numbers don't make sense, sir. His brothers are dead, that's too bad, but they're out of the equation. Sending men up there is bleeding heart crapola from three thousand miles away. One private is simply not worth a squad. Colonel anderson This one is. He's worth a lot more than that. Which is why I'm sending you, you're the best field officer there is. Yes and no, sir, what about Morgan? Fine officer, regular church goer, writes poetry, he might like a mission like this. And he's taller than me.
answer: That's enough, Captain, you have your orders. Major Thomas will fill you in.

question: Yes, sir.
answer: Good luck, John.

question: Thank you, sir. Crouch-runs and dives into a crater with Sarge. Put on your traveling shoes, Sarge, we're heading out.
answer: Caen?

question: I wish. You and I are taking a squad up to Ramelle on a public relations mission.
answer: You? Leading a squad?

question: Some private up there lost three brothers, got a ticket home.
answer: What about the company?

question: Simpson.
answer: Simpson? Jesus Christ on a fucking pogo stick!

question: I want Reiben on B.A.R; Jackson with his sniper rifle; Beasley, demolition.
answer: Beasley's dead.

question: Okay, Wade. Translators?
answer: Fresh out.

question: What about Talbot?
answer: Twenty minutes ago. Miller Damn, I'll go see if I can find another one. You get Reiben, Jackson and Wade, meet me at transport. Yes, sir.

question: Strides through the chaos, avoiding the passing vehicles. He sees his men and walks toward them. Reiben hurries up to Miller, pleading.
answer: Please, sir, you can't take me to Ramelle, I gotta go to Caen, sir, please, I told you, they make Caen lingerie there, it's beautiful, it's the best there is, it's...oh, please, sir...

question: Sorry, I need a B.A.R. man, you're the best.
answer: No, I'm not, Kaback is, honest. Or what about Faulkner? Or that little guy with the glasses?

question: Trust me, you're the best.
answer: But, sir...

question: I've got a line on one. Sergeant, I need a truck.
answer: Sorry, sir, fresh out of trucks, how 'bout a '38 Ford Roadster, hard-top, red with black interior.

question: White-walls?
answer: No white-walls, sir, there's a war on. NOT THERE, YOU GODDAMNED IDIOT, OVER THERE! I can't help you, sir.

question: A half-track, anything.
answer: Sorry, sir. Division is using everything on wheels to get up to Caen. How come you guys aren't going?

question: How about that jeep?
answer: That's General Gavin's. His lap dog told me if anyone breathes on it, I'll get busted and if anyone so much as touches it with their little finger, I'll get court marshaled. If you were to take it, they'd shoot me.

question: What's at Ramelle beside a lot of Germans.
answer: A paratrooper named Ryan. He's going home, if he's alive.

question: Senator's son?
answer: No, three brothers of his were killed in action. Command wants him out of there.

question: Damn...I got a couple brothers...
answer: We've got to make one stop. Wait here. I understand you speak French and German. Do you have an accent? Good, you've been re-assigned to me, we're going to Ramelle. That's my understanding. Do you have a problem with that, Corporal? I need a translator, all mine have been killed. It'll come back to you. Get your gear. A small one. Go, go...

question: We've got to make one stop. Wait here. I understand you speak French and German. Do you have an accent? Good, you've been re-assigned to me, we're going to Ramelle. That's my understanding. Do you have a problem with that, Corporal? I need a translator, all mine have been killed. It'll come back to you. Get your gear. A small one. Go, go...
answer: Captain, can I ask you a question?

question: Sure, Reiben.
answer: Where are you planning on putting Private Ryan, sir? It's just that it's kind of crowded back here, I was wondering if you're expecting to have more room on the way back?

question: Captain, I gotta tell you, the irony of this mission is fucking killing me.
answer: Yeah, how so?

question: I should be on my way to Caen, sir. It's like Beethoven, the guy's one of the greatest composers ever lived and he goes deaf. Go figure, I mean, who'd he piss off? And here I am, the Beethoven of ladies foundation garments, one step away from Caen, the center of the known lingerie universe and instead, I'm going to Ramelle to save some fucking private who's probably already dead.
answer: There's to be a bright side, look for it.

question: Sir, you know what Ramelle is famous for? Cheese. The rest of the company is going to Caen and we're going to the goddamned cheese capital of France. There is no bright side.
answer: There's always a bright side.

question: I'm listening, sir.
answer: Well, I, for one, like cheese.

question: Well, you're a happy idiot.
answer: How's the road up to St. Mere? Anybody getting through?

question: Hell, this is better than Coney Island!
answer: Just trying to make room for Ryan. Sarge? Directs Sarge off the road. They've got the road zeroed.

question: Just trying to make room for Ryan. Sarge? Directs Sarge off the road. They've got the road zeroed.
answer: Yanks the wheel, driving the jeep off the road. Jesus Christ!

question: They've got a hell of a spotter somewhere. S-curves, Sarge.
answer: Turns shallow curves without slowing down.

question: Sarge! Reverse! COME ON! YOU WANNA WALK?
answer: Captain, they got us zeroed.

question: FORWARD! FORWARD! NOW REVERSE!
answer: Uh, Captain...

question: PUSH!
answer: Uh, Captain... Oh, Captain...

question: I'm Jackson. I'm from West Fork, Tennessee. My pappy's a preacher. Him and his two brothers got a ministry, The Blessed Church of the Wandering Gospel.
answer: In West Fork?

question: In the back of a nineteen and thirty- one stretch Hudson with a big ole' trailer.
answer: No kidding.

question: I don't make jokes about things of, or related to, the preaching of the Holy Gospel, including the ministerial calling of my family.
answer: So they travel around from place to place and preach?

question: We got us a tent, forty-two feet across, eighteen feet at center, hundred-and-ten foldin' chairs. Circuit's eleven towns, covers all 'a Hasset County and most 'a Weller County. I expect that upon completion of my military service I will be joinin' said ministry.
answer: What about the Captain? Where's he from?

question: Who knows? It worked.
answer: Fine, you convince yourself you got a pack full of feathers and goddamned Private James Ryan can carry my fucking gear.

question: Reiben, you can be very unpleasant to be around sometimes.
answer: You want unpleasant? Just wait, I can do much better than this.

question: Upham, are you sure you've never been in combat? He's good.
answer: Cap'n, my feet are most uncomfortable.

question: Stay low.
answer: Dang! That was close!

question: Glad of it.
answer: On the other side of the street, crouches in a doorway with Jackson. Upham is a bit in shock, less from the nearness of the bullets than from what Miller just did for him.

question: DASHES across the street. Bring 'em over.
answer: Captain, I...

question: One at a time. Ducks out of the doorway and crouch- runs down the block. He passes a: Sees the dead and wounded, shows no reaction. Runs to: We had a jeep until a few hours ago, a nice one, it had a cute little flag with a couple of stars on it. We called in a strike on the eighty- eights that took it out, but it's the Kraut spotter that counts, wherever the hell that bastard is. Jackson.
answer: What is that?

question: What is that?
answer: Thirty-ought-six, Norton long-barrel with dual-groove, parallel rifling, elevated three-glass scope and a single-throw hammer.

question: The Army gave you that?
answer: Yep.

question: You must be a hell a shot.
answer: Not where I come from.

question: That must be four thousand yards.
answer: Forty-two-hundred, I figure.

question: Very far, they're not coming this way, they're going to take Caen first. Five, but we not staying, we're on our way to Ramelle. Yeah, you know about that? Wonderful. How do we get out of here? Yeah? Thanks. Let's find someplace to hole up.
answer: Sir, I'm sorry about what happened,

question: It was nothing.
answer: But you could have gotten killed and

question: Like I said, it was nothing. Don't bunch up.
answer: Did you see what he did, back there? He stepped right into the open, so I could get across.

question: Captain, could you please explain the math of this mission to me?
answer: Sure, what do you want to know?

question: Well, sir, in purely arithmetic terms, since when does six equal one? What's the sense in risking six guys to save one?
answer: Ours is not to reason why.

question: Huh?
answer: Never mind, don't worry, we'll pick up this kid, high-tail it back to division, everything'll work out fine.

question: I'd much rather die in Caen than Ramelle, sir. It's a personal thing.
answer: Reiben, there's a fairly good chance you're not going to die at all.

question: You have orders, too.
answer: Sir, I have an opinion on this matter.

question: I'd love to hear it.
answer: Seems to me, Cap'n, this mission is a serious misallocation of valuable military resources. Miller Go on. Well, sir, by my way a thinkin' I am a finely made instrument of warfare. What I mean by that is, if you was to put me with this here sniper rifle anywhere up to and includin' one mile from Adolf Hitler, with a clear line of sight, war's over.

question: Reiben, I want you to listen closely to Jackson. This is the way to gripe. Jackson, continue.
answer: Yes, sir. It seems to me, sir, that the entire resources of the United States Army oughta be dedicated to one thing and one thing only, and that is to put me and this here weapon on a rooftop, smack-dab in the middle of Berlin, Germany. Now I ain't one to question decisions made up on high, sir, but it seems to me that saving one private, no matter how grievous the losses of his family, is a waste of my God-given talent.

question: And what about you, Captain?
answer: Reiben, what's the matter with you? I don't gripe to you. I'm a captain. There's a chain of command. Griping goes one way, up, only up, never down. You gripe to me, I gripe to my superior officers. Up, get it? I don't gripe to you, I don't gripe in front of you. How long you been in the army?

question: I'm sorry, sir, I apologize. But if you weren't a captain, or if I were a major, what would you say?
answer: In that case, I would say this is an excellent mission, with an extremely valuable objective, worthy of my best efforts. In addition, as I pointed out earlier, I have a fondness for cheese and I hope to have the opportunity to sample some of the Ramelle products, when we arrive there, to see if they live up to their excellent reputation. Moreover, I feel heartfelt sorrow for the mother of Private James Ryan and I'm more than willing to lay down my life, and the lives of my men, especially you, Reiben, to help relieve her suffering. The men thoroughly enjoy the performance.

question: Sir, if you were not a captain, I would compliment you, now, for being an excellent liar.
answer: But I am a captain. If I were not a captain, I would thank you for the compliment and tell you that the ability to lie comes from being a top-notch poker player, which I am, having learned at the side of my mother who is, by popular acclaim, the best poker player in... ...my home town, which shall remain un-named. Any further thoughts on the subject?

question: Yes, sir, as a final note, I'd like to say, fuck our orders, fuck Ramelle, fuck the cheese capital of France and while we're at it, fuck Private James Ryan.
answer: I'll make a note of your suggestions but I'll leave that last one to you, especially if he's already dead. We move out in two hours, try and get some sleep.

question: I'll make a note of your suggestions but I'll leave that last one to you, especially if he's already dead. We move out in two hours, try and get some sleep.
answer: You ever going to open those letters? Miller keeps his eyes on the maps.

question: Maybe.
answer: It's not normal, not reading letters from home.

question: Since when have things been normal?
answer: You got me. Afraid of bad news?

question: Nope.
answer: Good news? You think they'll be alright?

question: They're fine. As long as they can gripe, they'll be alright.
answer: And what about you?

question: They guys here aren't going to be able to hold out until battalion shows up.
answer: Nope.

question: Command isn't going to let them withdraw and the Germans sure as hell aren't going to let them surrender.
answer: Three for three.

question: If we stayed, we could make a difference.
answer: You're kidding yourself.

question: You never know.
answer: I hope this boy Ryan is worth it.

question: Now you're the one kidding yourself. Hell of a mission.
answer: Yup, hell of a mission.

question: Rise and shine, boys. Let's go.
answer: Makes you feel small, doesn't it?

question: Thanks, but you may need these more than us, or Ryan. Let's move out. A couple of weeks. It started in Portsmouth when they brought us down for loading.
answer: Is it getting worse?

question: No. It comes and goes. It stops when I look at it.
answer: You may have to find yourself a new line of work, this one doesn't seem to agree with you anymore.

question: I'll be alright. It'll be light, soon. Let's pick it up. It looks like a Renoir.
answer: Yes. Do you know Sibelius' Fourth Symphony, The Normandy?

question: I've been humming it.
answer: I heard.

question: It seemed appropriate.
answer: You know classical music?

question: Some.
answer: Where are you from, Captain?

question: What's the pool up to?
answer: Over three-hundred.

question: I'll tell you what, if I'm still alive when it hits five-hundred, I'll let you know and we'll split the money.
answer: If that's the way you feel, why don't we wait until it's up to a thousand.

question: I don't expect to live that long.
answer: Five hundred, then.

question: Let's go, private.
answer: Five nights ago, he found this paratrooper caught in a tree with a broken leg. The leg got infected. Last night he went to Ville Cholet to get a doctor. The doctor refused to come and when he got back, this is what he found. The Krauts must have shown up while he was gone.

question: Did he see any sign of them?
answer: No, but he heard firing, just east, less that a kilometer.

question: Sarge, Upham, here. Jackson, Reiben, ten yards, either side.
answer: Rule of thumb, Captain, says you ought to detail this one, instead of going yourself.

question: Yeah? What rule of thumb is that?
answer: How about I go right, sir?

question: How about you take your position?
answer: How about...?

question: How about you shut up and take your position?
answer: Yes, sir.

question: Good luck, Captain.
answer: Don't need it, I'm a cat, I've got five lives.

question: The men said, nine.
answer: What do they know? I had nine, but I feel through the ice when I was seven, my brother pulled me out. Then I used one when a grenade landed in my foxhole in Sicily, it was a dud. I figure one on the beaches, one on the cliffs and two getting here.

question: That only leaves three.
answer: Plenty. Ready?

question: Fuck Private James Ryan, fuck him, just fuck the goddamned son-of-a- bitch.
answer: Shut up, will you?

question: You shut up, this is the most fucked up mission I ever heard of. Goddamned Ryan, fuck the little bastard.
answer: Just shut up, Ryan didn't kill Wade.

question: Keep it down. We've got to find someplace to hole up for a bit.
answer: You alright?

question: Let's just find someplace. Rest. One hour. Jackson, Reiben, perimeter. Keep your eyes open. I'm going to re-con. What was the name of that kid at Anzio, the one who got his face burned off?
answer: Vecchio.

question: Yeah, Vecchio, I couldn't remember his name, he was a good kid, remember how he used to walk on his hands and sing that song about the man on flying trapeze?
answer: Yeah.

question: You know why I'm such a good officer? Because of my mother. Have I ever told you about her?
answer: Bits and pieces.

question: She's the best poker player you ever saw. My father used to go to these Saturday night games and lose his shirt. Finally, my mother gave him an ultimatum, either she gets a regular seat at the table or she locks him in every Saturday night. He squawked and so did his buddies but after a while they gave in and from the first night she sat down, she never lost. She could read those cocky bastards like they were playing open hands. And he bluffs? He had sixteen levels of bullshit. Her eyes, the tone of her voice, her bets, her jokes, the way she sipped her coffee, she was a master. She won more money on shit hands than anyone in the history of the game. Every Saturday night, my father would lose two, three hundred bucks and she'd win it all back and then some. And I'd stand there, glued to her shoulder, from the time I was five years old, watching every hand, every move, studying how she did it. That's why I'm such a good officer, I can look at a man's face and tell you exactly what he's holding, and if it's a shit hand, I know just what cards to deal him.
answer: And what about your own hand?

question: No problem. A pair of deuces? Less? So what? I bluff. It used to tear me apart when I'd get one of my men killed, but what was I supposed to do? Break down in front of the ones who were standing there waiting for me to tell them what to do? Of course not, so I bluffed, and after a while, I started to fall for my own bluff. It was great, it made everything so much easier. Sarge Is that why your hand's been shaking? It could be worse. You know the first thing they teach you at O.C.S.? Lie to your men.
answer: Oh, yeah?

question: Not in so many words, but they tell you you can have all the firepower in the world and if your men don't have good morale, it's not worth a damn. So if you're scared or empty or half-a-step from a Section Eight, do you tell your men? Of course not. You bluff, you lie.
answer: And how do you bluff yourself?

question: Simple, numbers. Every time you kill one of your men, you tell yourself you just saved the lives of two, three, ten, a hundred others. We lost, what, thirty-one on the cliffs? I'll bet we saved ten times that number by putting out those guns. That's over three hundred men. Maybe five hundred. A thousand. Then thousand. Any number you want. See? It's simple. It lets you always choose mission over men.
answer: Except this time, the mission IS a man.

question: That's the rub. I liked Wade. Who's Ryan? If they're both standing in front of me and I have to shoot one or the other, how do I choose? Look at my hand, there it goes again.
answer: John, I've got to tell you, I think you're about used up.

question: I think you're right, Keith.
answer: You want me to take over?

question: No, but if I get any worse, you'll have to relieve me.
answer: Just what I want to do.

question: You know Wade was the eleventh of the twelve, you're the last one still alive.
answer: I know.

question: Don't let yourself get killed, if you do, they might make me give back the medal and then I won't be able to lip off to colonels anymore.
answer: I'll do my best.

question: Thanks for drawing that machine gun off me.
answer: You're welcome, John.

question: But, that's my personal brand of stupidity, I feel kind of proprietary about it, if you do it again, you're busted.
answer: Yes, sir.

question: Well now I'm saying we're moving out. Get off your ass. What the hell's the matter with you, Jackson?
answer: Sir, I ain't feeling so chipper on account of Wade.

question: Who's Wade? I said, who the hell is Wade?
answer: Sir, I understand what you're doin', but I respectfully request permission to grieve in my own manner.

question: You'll grieve the way I tell you to goddamned grieve. There is no Wade, there was one, but he died a long time ago, he's been dead for so long you can hardly remember his name, you understand?
answer: Sir, I understand. I don't like it, but I understand.

question: I've given this a lot of thought, sir. The best thing that could happen is, we find Ryan and he's dead.
answer: Why's that?

question: Well, sir, consider the possibilities. A
answer: Except for the last part, that one's not bad.

question: B
answer: I don't like that one.

question: Neither do I, sir. C
answer: But we accomplish the mission.

question: Maybe. But what if he dies on the way back? you see what I'm saying, sir? The best possible situation is, he's dead, we find his body, more or less intact, we grab one of his dog-tags and high-tail it back to the beach, or better yet, we head over to Caen and catch up with division.
answer: Has anyone ever told you, you're officer material?

question: No, sir.
answer: That's a mystery to me.

question: Puts away the binoculars and jerks his head for his men to follow, low, along the wall. The men are happy to do so, looking back nervously at the German tanks.
answer: Looks like they've been having a hell of a party, here, Captain.

question: ON THE BRIDGE! WE'RE COMING IN.
answer: What if our guys open up, sir?

question: You're only allowed to shoot at Germans, that's one of the rules.
answer: Have it your way, Captain.

question: Yes. We've been sent to get you out of here. You're going home. Sergeant, we're moving out and I'm taking you and your men with me. I'm giving you new orders, Sergeant. I'm not going to leave you and your men here to get killed. Get them together, we're moving out.
answer: No, sir.

question: Come on, Private, you're going home.
answer: No, sir.

question: Private. I'm sorry about your brothers but staying here and getting yourself killed isn't going to help.
answer: Sir, if the Krauts are holding this bridge when division shows up, our guys are going to be sitting ducks.

question: This bridge cannot be held. The Germans have two companies less than three miles from here. They have tanks. Private, if you want to commit suicide, that's your choice, but you're going to have to wait until after I get you back to the beach. And you're not going to take these men with you.
answer: I'm not leaving, sir.

question: The hell you aren't, you're comin' with me if I have to drag you every inch of the way. You hear me, Private?
answer: I hear you sir, but I'm not leaving.

question: Listen you little son-of-a-bitch you're coming with me or I'll...I'll...
answer: What are you going to do, sir, shoot me?

question: In that case... I vote we stay. Reiben, the B.A.R., there. Jackson, get up on the bridgekeepers hut with your sniper rifle. Sarge, you and Upham move that machine gun so it can cover the left flank, it's worthless where it is. Forrest, I want a full inventory of all your weapons, ammo and ordnance. Go.
answer: Thank you, sir.

question: Yeah, yeah. I want you right next to me, no matter where I go, you understand?
answer: Yes, sir.

question: Those guns are close. Let's hope they don't change their mind.
answer: What do you think?

question: Well, if we had ten times the men and a lot more ammo, we might stand a chance, but not against those tanks.
answer: What are we going to do?

question: Let's hope, because we're sure as hell not going to do any damage to them with what we have here.
answer: What about our grenades?

question: Those are Tigers, they have six-inch armor, they don't even notice grenades.
answer: Would they notice and eighty-eight?

question: Sure, you got one?
answer: The Germans do.

question: Out of the mouth of babes. Upham, you've got to learn the difference between whining and griping. You can't just rely on natural ability, you've got to study and practice.
answer: But, sir...

question: There you go again, that's whining, that's not okay.
answer: Goddamn it, sir...

question: What do you think?
answer: I think I'm we got that eighty-eight.

question: I mean, Ryan, what do you think of him?
answer: He ain't half-bad, I guess.

question: I guess.
answer: He ain't Wade.

question: I'm in my backyard, lying in my hammock, with my arm around my wife, listening for the sound of breaking glass.
answer: Say what, Cap'n?

question: You see, I've got the best house in all of Addley. It's not the biggest house, but it's got the best location, right next to the junior high baseball field. The garage windows face left field. The guy who owned the house before me had these heavy screen S put over them. The first thing I did when I bought the place was take off those screens. Two-hundred-twenty- two yards from home plate to my garage windows. It takes a hell of a junior high kid to hit a ball that far. I look at my garage windows as a Motivator and a way to scout the kids coming up, the ones who are going to give us a shot at the state championship. I lay there in my hammock and every time I hear the sound of breaking glass, I know we're one step closer to winning it all.
answer: Don't that get kind of expensive, Cap'n?

question: It's worth it.
answer: To each, his own.

question: Knows what that means. He hears the TIGHTEN IT UP! HERE THEY COME!
answer: On the bridgekeeper's hut. Picking off German soldiers who follow the tank.

question: JACKSON!
answer: Knows what's coming but he holds his position, continuing to pick off German soldiers.

question: Shoves the FINAL SHELL into the breech of the eighty-eight. Pats Ryan on the back. Grabs a SATCHEL CHARGE. Races through the debris. Trailed by BULLETS.
answer: With the machine gun. Covers Miller. Keeping most of the German infantry down.

question: Is almost there. He arms the satchel charge. Throws the satchel charge under the tank. Rolls off the edge of the bridge. Lands on the embankment below. HOLD IT! HOLD IT! Goddamn it!
answer: More tanks... Ryan Lot's of them The fear on their faces turns to resignation. They know that they are dead men. They settle into their positions, and prepare to fire and die.

question: Miller, Company B, Second Rangers, that's Private Richard Reiben and that's Private James Ryan, Hundred- and-First Airborne. Walks to the bodies. He kneels down next to Sarge and looks at him for a long moment. Then, with a steady hand, he takes one of Sarge's two dog-tags. Then he does the same to Jackson and Upham. Stands and walks back to Reiben and Ryan. He hands the dog-tags to Ryan who grips them tightly and nods in thanks.
answer: Captain?

question: Yes, Private.
answer: Upham and Jackson, what were they like?

question: Upham? Good kid, smart, he was writing a book.
answer: Yeah?
